results.title: Radio day
results.brief_description: A promotional exercise that shows a day in the life of radio station 3XY in Melbourne. Although most of the activities carried out in a commercial radio station are depicted, there is no attempt to explain why and as such this production does little to demystify the process. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Bingo, bridesmaids and braces
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Tristram Miall and Film Australia
results.brief_description: In this documentary the lives of three working class women are examined as they grow up from the “not so innocent” age of fourteen, to “it’s happening too fast” at eighteen, through to “well we survived”, at the ripe young age of 26. During these years we witness the women confronting the very real issues of teenage pregnancy, love versus sex, and career choices.

results.title: Jump the fence
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Lucy MacLaren and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Two young girls who feel restricted at home decide to escape in a gelati van. After a short burst of freedom they end up in Winlaton, a girls’ training centre.

results.title: Mamadrama
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Amber Films, Arte and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: An Australian documentary examining the portrayal of Jewish mothers on the big screen. From an early age filmmaker Monique Schwarz was puzzled by the discrepancy between the domineering and emasculating Jewish mothers typically represented on film, and her own mother, a Holocaust survivor. “Mamadrama” consequently has a strong personal touch, via the reflections of Schwarz and interviews with directors Paul Mazursky, Paul Bogart, and Larry Peerce, and actress Lainie Kazan. In addition to well-known Hollywood movies “Mamadrama” uses rare footage from early silent films, Yiddish language features and Israeli films. The tone of the documentary is reflective rather than critical; the most intriguing moments emerge from the candour with which the interviewees discuss their own mothers.

results.title: Job No. 1112
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Dahl Collings, Geoffrey Collings and Collings Productions
results.brief_description: Describes the engineering design of the roof of the Sydney Opera House and the development of the architectural form of the roof from the original concept to its final realisation. Shows the construction of the roof with details of many special techniques developed to cope with its unusual building problems. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.

results.title: William Dobell
results.creator_credit: Dahl Collings, Geoffrey Collings and Collings Productions
results.brief_description: William Dobell has been acclaimed the greatest portrait and character painter of the twentieth century. The film with some 85 examples, reviews and interprets the artist’s work and development from his early days of struggle in London to his success in later times. This review of the work of Dobell includes not only some of his great portraits but also some examples of his early paintings. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Palm Beach
results.creator_credit: Albie Thoms and Albie Thoms Productions
results.brief_description: A quasi-documentary fiction film about the suburban sub-culture of of Sydney’s northern beach areas. It is, simultaneously, a fast-paced thriller involving surf, drugs and rock n roll. Forty eight hours in the lives of a handful of young Australians. Paul was looking for work … Joe was looking on. Stars Nat Young and Bryan Brown. Rated: M

results.title: Pitcha this : youth telling stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Jade Colgan, Kalimna Andy, Lionel Austin, Nicole Hucks, Rebecca Phillips, Simone Andy, Teialah Mason, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous youth tell their own stories about who they are and where they come from. They proudly describe the places and people that inspire them and connect them to their heritage. In doing so, they provide an examination of what it is to grow up Indigenous in Australia in the 1990s, how to engage with your spirituality and identity today.

results.title: Where she belongs...
results.creator_credit: Nicole Hucks, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nikki Butler pays tribute to her Nana, a strong, knowledgeable Aboriginal women. Despite being a part of the Stolen Generation and growing up away from her land, Nana has taught Butler so much about her heritage, culture and land. Butler hopes to be with her when Nana does finally return home.
